awd_titl_txt: EAGER research: An instrument setup for measuring air-water gas exchange by underwater eddy covariance in shallow-water marine systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI's requests funding to design, construct, and test a new instrument setup that will allow measurements of air-water gas exchange in shallow-water marine environments. This effort will benefit a large and broad group of aquatic scientists who use gas exchange estimates in their ecosystem studies. In addition, undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in high-frequency data acquisition with complex instruments and analysis of "big data" produced within this project.

The PI's will design, construct, and test a new instrument setup that will allow this new application of the aquatic eddy covariance technique in shallow-water marine environments.  This will be accomplished by applying their aquatic eddy covariance technique right below the air-water interface to measure air-water gas exchange. If successful, the new instrument setup will significantly improve the accuracy of gas exchange measurements for shallow-water marine systems, and as important, enhance the temporal and spatial resolution of these measurements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Air-water exchanges of oxygen and the greenhouse gases carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), and nitrous oxide (N2O) are important variables in studies of shallow-water marine environments but are often highly uncertain, if at all available. For example, emission rates of CH4 and N2O from under-water seagrass meadows are largely unknown. This mismatch is partly due to a lack of reliable methods to quantify and study these emissions in the natural environment.

The goal of this project was to help filling this knowledge gap by testing a new high-tech approach for measuring gas exchange under water. This approach, called the aquatic eddy covariance technique (Berg et al. 2022; https://berg.evsc.virginia.edu/), measures the turbulent transport of gases to and from underwater environments such as seagrass meadows and oyster reefs. It was first developed for measuring exchange rates between the seafloor and the water above. In this project, the technique was turned ?upside down? and positioned right below the air-water surface to measure gas exchange between the surface water and the air above. The instrument developed for this task was designed to move up and down on a pole as the water depth changes due to tides (see included photo).

The instruments tests were successful and have already pointed to important weaknesses of traditional methods for determining gas exchange, especially when used in calm weather conditions. The new instrument is currently being used in the NSF-funded Virginia Coast Reserve Long-Term Ecological Research project and is also being deployed in a newly funded NSF project focusing on improving greenhouse gas emission estimates for shallow-water marine systems. It is expected that this new approach will help improving the accuracy of estimates of marine greenhouse gas fluxes in the future. Project results were presented at one national and two international meetings, and preparation of scientific publications describing both the new approach and obtained results are underway.      

References:

Berg, P., M. Huettel, R. N. Glud, C. E. Reimers, and K. M. Attard. 2022. Aquatic eddy covariance: the method and its contributions to defining oxygen and carbon fluxes in marine environments. Annual review of marine science 14.
